content: hello welcome to bard's craft in this video i'll make a very quick wall
terrain for tables of gaming so one day when i
was cutting xps foam i tried using a saw and discovered these
instant stone textures by accident before making any terrain out of this i
tried a few ways of cutting to get the best textures it turns out
that the foam likes cuts in one way better than the other when i cut again
in a different direction the textures get worse
you can see these flimsy half attached pieces here
they will do no good for our terrain so we begin the craft by choosing this
side i began by cutting out a long piece that
will probably be enough for this build what am i building
at this point i had two options strange dwarven walls or
post-apocalyptic reinforced walls tough choice well while cutting i held
the saw vertically to get nice somewhat
consistent textures good this cutout was straight
enough next the loose foam junk was easily
removed i simply moved about with my finger to
clean the surface nice and there we have it the instant
stone textures i then tried cutting the top surface to
get textures there as well but that didn't work at all something
about the structure of the xps foam makes it easier to cut
in certain angles okay now i knew what i was gonna do as i
heard dwarven chanting in the distance the
untextured top surface will be covered in metal constructions
yeah i began cutting the bits i need for my terrain
i sawed a few roughly 12 centimeter bits some five centimeter-ish bits
and then i planned how i will lay this out on bases
three pieces of terrain should be enough i already have
limited space before basing i cut out the glossy factory surface
of my bits in this way glue sticks better to the surface
great then i drew the rough shapes of my bases
on a piece of hardboard on the bases i left some room for
little bits such as this dwarven head i sort out the bases and then
slightly beveled the edges of the hardboard when beveled terrain will
better merge into whatever game table or battle mat
you have okay i believe my wall layouts have

here i made sure to make spaces large

next step is to throw on sand on the

like using plenty of glue to make sure that
the sand stays in place without the use of any further
ceiling ok this dwarf statue head is from a set
of giants i glued it together first then attached
it to the terrain in the most sophisticated
way here i'm making what's called a glue and
sand pile this pile is excellent for attaching the
head i was able to push the glue dwarf head
so that it appears to be partially submerged
into the soil very good
all of this glue takes much time to dry but not if we place this
in sunlight okay now the sacred oats are back on the
crafting table well the cardstock package at least i'll
use this material for the top of the wall
i began by cutting roughly wall wide strips using my
utility blade then i checked the fit on the walls they
look good the pieces should all be slightly
overlapping on all sides i was happy with my idea so i glued the
cardstock pieces on
on this larger wall the cardstock goes
over the gap here now we have what can be called a gate
of course this terrain will go well together with other
dwarf terrain i've built therefore i glued on additional cardstock details
by the way here is the epic dwarf terrain playlist
anyway for the details i cut a slightly thinner
strip of cardboard that i shaped like this
i also cut a few different bits of dwarf approved
shape as usual an idea for you for higher quality terrain you could
make the top parts from a thicker board now it was getting rather late but i
still wanted a few simple platforms for my dwarves to stand on my solution
was simple i cut out a piece of the hardboard we
used for the bases earlier then using barbecue sticks i glued in
the platforms poke the stick into the foam
then put on the platform easy and looks great
next i cut cardstock strips and glued
them on the side of the platforms i let the
pieces overlap quite a bit so that sand can be nicely
poured onto the surface later these were unnecessarily tricky to
get in place using pva glue so i recommend
super glue or hot glue if you decide to make
something similar yeah and then i applied plenty of glue again
and applied sand on the platform the surface will look similar to the
ground you may ask why would there be so much
sand and stones up on these platforms good question dwarves have very heavy
boots that get sand stuck in them also dwarves
feel safer when sitting on crude rocks indeed i let all of this dry
overnight next morning i checked the terrain good
no loose pieces and tiny amounts of warping
no problem i proceeded by priming with a matte black and met a rather unfriendly
fellow i was able to cover two of these before
running out of spray what a shame i painted the rest by
hand i took my crappy paints and started mixing for painting the ground i
mixed a medium brown i thinned the paint with
some water and applied it over the entire base
the platforms are also painted with the same brown
alright next i mixed a gray and over-brushed the ground
yeah the stones do look a bit too large for miniature scale
the next time i'll use finer sand after working with the medium grey
i also touched some areas with a lighter grey
i continued by painting the walls using the same paint
first a rough brushing with dark grey then we move to medium grey and
light gray i do all of this painting without waiting for the paint to dry in
this way i can blend the colors a bit while i save time
after waiting for the paint to dry i dry brushed with
a white here we can start seeing and judging the instant stone textures what
do you think i then hit the edges with a bit more
paint on the brush okay starting to look like something
next i painted the top parts with copper just sloppily
dry brushing will do the sides of the platforms and
the dwarven head is also painted copper afterwards i painted another layer with
more paint on the brush streaking over some parts to make the
surface uneven then i dry brushed gently with
gold this is mainly for highlighting the edges of the cardstock
details the head on the other hand i brush with plenty of gold paint
now we move to my favorite oil paints as washes i took some brown oil paint and
thinned it down with some white spirit i apply this gently on about everything
most importantly on the low to mid sections of the wall
and then i smudge it around i also apply it on the ground
and on the metal surfaces to help even out the wash
i also worked it with a piece of toilet paper
what i have noticed when washing and weathering with oil paints
is that i don't have to care much about painting the base layers
as long as the paint job looks okay the oil paint will fix the rest
that's why i have painted the walls in boring black and grey
i knew these oil paints would add the needed color
next i worked with a dark green oil wash this i applied a bit more sparingly well
not quite i applied it on less surface area but
where i applied it i let it flow down along
the walls with this i also washed the dwarf head
which now looked very nice
